I fell in love with this game's concept (and presentation) when I first saw it being played by the Giant Bomb crew. After months of impatiently waiting for the release, my friends and I had to wait a bit more before the online functionality was available. Today it came, and even though there were bugs, the gameplay shone through and proved to be just as fun as I expected.

This is a great game to play with your friends. 2 players is fun but it gets exponentially better with more. The best part? Your movement is client-side, meaning you can comfortably play this with people across the world.

The gameplay is the real selling point, but the presentation deserves special mention as well. The art style fits the hilarious quirky gameplay very well, and is well animated. The sound effects are a perfect compliment to the visuals, from the UI to the sound of your character's head bumping a ceiling. And the sheep makes adorable noises!

Aside from the bugs which the developers are working hard to eradicate, this is a great example of how to make a fun online party game. Don't give this a second thought if you're looking for a good time full of laughs with friends.

reviewText:
tl;dr : Despite the current online bugs, the gameplay, presentation, and overall experience of Ultimate Chicken Horse is well worth the current price, and it's only going to improve with time and community involvement.

Ultimate Chicken Horse is an enjoyable party platformer where you and up to three other players set up obstacles to impede your opponents while still keeping it possible for yourself. For the purposes of this review, please know that I have not used the local play options (due to a lack of people to play with near me) and have only been using the online beta.

This title is one that I was interested in from the moment I came across it prior to its actual release. As an avid fan of platformers and games where you have a certain degree of creative control (level editors), this game fit me like a glove. And once I saw that the game was going to recieve the online treatment, I knew I needed it ASAP.

I have no regrets.

On its surface, the gameplay is your average platformer. You can move with WASD, jump with the spacebar, and interact with certain elements of the world with your mouse. There is a wall jump mechanic, and you can even single wall jump. The best part: it all feels very fluid and responsive. But once you add in the multiplayer race aspect and the level customization, the game becomes much, much more complicated. You want to make it possible, but you also want to make it very difficult so that you and only you can finish. You also want to figure out the fastest way to complete the level (which is set up differently every time you play) so that you have higher chances of winning.

There is a very good variety of level gimmicks available to you, but most of them need to be unlocked. That's not necessarily a bad thing though: the two stages that are available to you from the get-go, while fairly basic, are good for honing your skills in the game in a relatively safe environment. My personal favorite stage is unfortunately the one that you unlock last, but I can't really fault the developers for putting it there because the gimmick is fairly eye-straining.

For all you fans of hats out there (and I know you are out there), the game offers a decent selection of characters and character specific cosmetic items for use in game. All characters are balanced equally, so no one will get an advantage if they choose to use one character over another. The current build of the online beta as of the time of me writing this review has some issues with cosmetics, so I would recommend local play if you can swing it if you want to use them.

Finally, the current online beta runs exceptionally well for being a beta. There are public games available for anyone at most times of the day, and hosting a public game is as simple as specifying a region and pressing a button. If you don't have people to play with locally, you can probably find someone online to play with. Be warned: there is no chat right now, but one might be planned for the future. If you feel the need for a chat, I would recommend waiting for a bit before purchasing. Last I checked there is an emote system coming soon, but even then I'm aware that doesn't work for everyone.

If you are a fan of platformers and level editors, I highly recommend that you get this game. I don't think you'll be disappointed.

reviewText:
Ultimate Chicken Horse is a competitive multiplayer platformer, with a twist. You need to place objects in the world to make it possible for you to reach the end, but harder for others to follow you.

The gameThe strength of this game lies in the ever-evolving levels. What once was as simple as jumping across five platforms, soon turns into a death race with black holes and death traps everywhere. The game is arguably going to be at its best when played locally because of how easy it is to communicate, plot and yell at your friends. It might still be fun using skype or similar, but it remains to be seen how well this game holds up when playing with complete strangers whom you can’t talk to.

This game features a fair amount of unlockable stages and costume pieces, so the game will remain fun as you keep playing it. The process of unlocking could easily have been a grind, but they managed to avoid that by adding something new after every game. The process of gaining the levels or costume is very interesting and unique: you have to, while competing, build something to get to the box that contains the unlockable. This leads to a team effort to mess everybody’s chances of winning up, and more often than not makes the rest of that match a lot more interesting.

There are a lot of parts, all of which can be used together in amazing ways. For example, you can use the rather ordinary platform with a saw, put some honey on it, and have an instant death trap for anyone who lands on it. And it only gets crazier as the game goes on, as more and more parts get placed. And if the level gets too hard, you always can still destroy some particularly troublesome parts. No parts will ever be used in the exact same way twice, and no game will be the same. It’s the perfect system to give infinite replayability.

Each game will take about 5 minutes to complete, which is the perfect length for this game. Play sessions will generally be longer than that though, when everyone keeps wanting to play one more time. All of the game rules can be changed – if there’s something that’s not quite right for what you currently want, you can most likely change that.

Summary+ Ever changing levels
+ Lots of parts
+ Interesting possibilities for interactions between parts
+ Short games and simple to set up

(-) Online may not be as good as local play

ConclusionI can find nothing bad to say about this game. The only thing that could possibly keep me from playing this, is its local play requirement and limited fun otherwise. But if you’re looking for local play game, then look no further than this.

reviewText:
More Reviews @ TheVideogameBacklog.com

This has to be one of the weirdest titles I’ve read in a long time. Along with that: it is also one of the more imaginative games I’ve played in a long time. Mixing up platforming with player-created-on-the-spot levels is genius.

While this game can be played with two people, or yourself and three other controllers, The Ultimate Chicken Horse is a dish best served with three other people (always better with friends)! As the level changes after every round as dictated by each player, the levels only get crazier and crazier. Unless someone uses the bomb and cleans it up a little. However, sometimes some spring cleaning is in order unless you don’t really want to progress.

Allowing on-line play was one of the smartest moves for Clever Endeavour Games. It’s not something that I can remember many small party games like this having missed lately, but it is something I could see someone taking a stance on. “Get your friends over like we did back in the day.” That’s weird to some people, but that was the norm back when I was a kid. It’s buggy currently, but they are diligently working on it. All this to say: it will still be more fun with your buds right there to punch.

I can understand the way multplayer is done currently, but it’s not my favorite. Given the flavor of the game, a more open multiplayer would have been more appreciated. However, since trying to make my own game and getting caught up with tiny details not working, if it was this “port-forwarding-friend-menu”method or nothing, then this trumps any complaint. I simply got used to this method of connecting with Magicite, but didn’t really appreciate it because of the lack of friends playing the same game. I like these type of games while not many of my buds would be willing to drop as little change down as Ultimate Chicken Horse costs. A more fluid, server-based multiplayer would have opened the floodgates to a more populated online experience in an ideal world. It could very well have been a lot of time spent coding and then been underused and that time could have been better spent. There are to many variables and let’s just say that I’m happy to at least have the option.

Score: Tasty!

Ultimate Chicken Horse is pretty darn unique. It still surprises me that some devs can come up with something like this out of nowhere when it feels like it should have been a part of our gaming library for a long time now. There are a lot of tools to hinder you and your friends with and enough levels to add some variety to the gameplay. Ultimate Chicken Horse is definitely worth picking up if you’ve got some buds that enjoy good platforming fun-time.
